The total cost to Government of this rescue package is £12.85 billion.
How to pay for it?
Cancel the £12.5bn of corporate tax reliefs scheduled for 2022-23 (announced in the March 2021 Budget). 7/7

That increase equates to extra £1,040 per year (c.£6 billion) Winter Fuel Payment of £300 per year could also be extended to households claiming Universal Credit (£1.65 billion).
Additionally for pensioner households, the winter fuel payment could be doubled to £600 (£1.9b) 6/7

That would add a further £832 to gross pay and an increase of over £1,800 on the current £8.91 rate.
We need the £20 cut in Universal Credit to be reversed and for that £20 uplift to be extended to legacy benefits – mostly disabled people on Employment Support Allowance. 5/7

For families on social security or low pay, the cost of living crisis risks a significant rise in child poverty, evictions and destitution.
At the lower end of the pay bracket, if the minimum wage is increased to £10 per hour, instead of the scheduled £9.50 in April. 4/7

Someone on UK median salary would need 5% pay increase this year to meet rising costs.
That means ensuring unions are able to fight for fair pay by repealing anti-union laws, and for the Government to ensure a minimum 5% pay settlement for all public sector workers  £3.3b 3/7

A comprehensive rescue package is needed to provide people with the security they need, including:
5% public sector pay rise £3.3bn
Universal Credit increase £6.0bn
WFP to UC households £1.65bn
Double WFP to pensioners £1.9bn
Total £12.85b 2/7

6/ This is the second report we've produced on economic policy and Coronavirus. Before the Govt announced its Job Retention Scheme, we published a report with proposals on wages, welfare, and wellbeing: https://t.co/bvPCDL2Z6Y. We will keep pressing the Govt on all of this.

5/ The Govt must announce relief for renters, no utility disconnections, and close loopholes in its self-employment scheme, which may exclude up to 2 million self-employed people. All these changes are practical, deliverable, and urgent.

4/ On social security: Universal Credit loans should be turned into grants. There must be increases to Child Benefit, Carer's Allowance, and UC, with consideration given to the New Economics Foundation's proposal of a minimum income guarantee.

3/ On statutory sick pay: the Govt must remove the Lower Earnings Limit, which means if you earn under £118 a week you don't get it. It should increase the level of statutory sick pay and make clear that it applies to all workers, including those in insecure work.

2/ On income support: the Job Retention Scheme, while welcome, doesn't apply to workers on reduced hours, carers, or to workers employed after 28 February. The Govt must include workers on reduced hours, carers, and workers employed after 28 February, in the Scheme.
